title: Welcome to our project  Bike analyses in Montpellier during  Tour de France
text:
Context

Instructions

The brief for this project was to carry out a survey of cycle traffic in Montpellier, through the analysis of datasets such as Montpellier Méditerranée Métropole’s VéloMagg bike runs, cyclist and pedestrian counts and data from the open road map.


This project had to combine aspects of interactive visualisation and the creation of a website. We had a choice of temporal resolution and the data was available from 2020 to 2024.



Problematic

We decided that our project would focus on the following question: ‘What is the impact of the Tour de France 2023 on the behaviour of cyclists in Montpellier before, during and after the event?’.



Aim

The goal is to analyze whether this sporting event, which took place in July 2023, has had an impact on the habits of cyclists in the city of Montpellier.



Hypothesis

Based in part on the work of Charrier et al., 2019 and our personal reflections, we believe that a high-profile event such as the Tour de France can encourage people to cycle, during or after the Tour de France period. We have therefore made the assumption that the number of cyclists will increase during the period of the Tour de France and the following weeks.

title: Welcome to our project  Bike analyses in Montpellier during  Tour de France
text:
Analyses

We decided to structure our analyses in order to compare several time periods, but always focusing on the dates of the Tour de France. That is, we compared the cycling traffic:



Statistics: between periods of 3 months (before, during and after the Tour de France), and between weeks (see graph).


Interactive map: between the different days of the week.


Video: between different times of the day.

title: Welcome to our project  Bike analyses in Montpellier during  Tour de France
text:
Data

To carry out this study, we selected several types of data.


Firstly, we retrieved data on the journeys made by VéloMagg bikes between stations in the VéloMagg network in the Montpellier metropolitan area.


Secondly, we have retrieved data for each of the bicycle counters (eco-counters) in production in the Montpellier Metropolitan Area, showing the number of bicycles (and pietons in some cases) counted. The daily data is the total of the previous day’s count. This information is divided into as many files as there are eco-counters. Each eco-counter is identified by a serial number, which we were able to find and associate with its latitude and longitude.


All the data we have selected was extracted between April 2023 and October 2023. This corresponds to 3 months before the Tour de France and 3 months after, which we thought was a good margin for observing changes and which is just over half a year (7 months).


We have processed and re-organised this data so that it can be used in various scripts (fully available on our Github page) to produce graphs, maps and a video.

title: Sources
text:
General

The guidelines for this project were provided by our teachers, and are available on this page.


In terms of content and form, it was our collective work that led to this result. However, we drew inspiration from several pages of documentation, help, templates, etc. to arrive at this final result.


Below is a list of the external elements that enabled us to bring this project to fruition.

title: Sources
text:
Hypothesis

To make an hypothesis from our problem, we based on the work of Charrier et al., 2019:


Charrier, D., Jourdan, J., Bourbillères, H., Djaballah, M., & Parmantier, C. (2019). L’impact social des grands événements sportifs : Réflexions théoriques et méthodologiques à partir de l’Euro 2016. Movement and Sports Sciences - Science et Motricite. https://doi.org/10.1051/sm/2019029

title: Sources
text:
Visuals

For the graphic charter we used on the site, we took care to ensure that the contrasts respected the standards. To do this, we used the WebAIM site .


For the logos, we used the Content Delivery Network for JavaScript icon database.


Finally, the image of the bike is available at this link.

title: Sources
text:
Slides

To create the slides, we mainly used the documentation for Quarto presentations and Quarto’s Revealjs theme to help us.


The various images we used are available via the following links:



Bike.


Logo of Tour de France.


 Velomagg .


 EcoCompters .


Logo of  Quarto .


Logo of  Python .


 Arrow .


 Cross .

title: Statistics
text:
Introduction

On this page, we present a short preliminary statistical analysis of the data we selected (see home page for a explanation of our data).


Our question was “What is the impact of the Tour de France 2023 on the behaviour of cyclists in Montpellier before, during and after the event?” and we hypothesized that there would be an increase in the number of people cycling during and after the Tour de France period.

title: Statistics
text:
Methods

We used sorted data corresponding to the number of bicycles passing in front of counters located in the city of Montpellier and compiled them into a single dataset. The statistical analyses focused on the following periods :



Before the Tour de France : April to June.


During the Tour de France : July 1st to July 23rd.


After the Tour de France : late July to October.



We carried out a number of statistical analyses to see if our hypothesis could be validated. These analyses are not intended to be taken literally, as there are many other parameters to be taken into account, but they are a short preliminary study of our data.


We began by performing descriptive analyses to give us a visual representation of our data. We then carried out tests to check the normality and homogeneity of the variances in order to choose the appropriate statistical test. Finally, we performed the test and compared the results with our hypothesis.

title: Statistics
text:
Results

We started by conducting descriptive analyses to get a first idea of our data. We found an average of 610.06 passes in front of eco-counters during the period before the Tour de France 523.07 passes during the Tour de France and 599.80 passes after the Tour de France. We see that there seems to be a slight decrease during the Tour de France, which would be the opposite of our hypothesis, but we will see if this difference is significant.


Following our descriptive analyses, we obtained the following graph:



This graph shows the total number of bicycles passing in front of the city of Montpellier’s eco-counters per week. Please note that this data does not correspond to the number of bicycles, as a bicycle may be counted several times if it passes in front of several counters. This data therefore corresponds to the total number of times cyclists pass in front of a counter in Montpellier. We can see that the Tour de France period is highlighted in green.


Visually, we can see that there does not seem to be an increase during the period of the Tour de France compared with the periods before and after. We also note that there is a sharp decrease in the number of crossings in front of a meter during the period of August and that it goes back to early September.


We continued by checking the homogeneity of variances and normality. Then, given that normality was not verified, we performed a Kruskal Wallis test (because we had several independent groups and only one variable of interest). We obtained the following graph to represent the differences between our groups.



This graph is a boxplot that represents the number of passes in front of eco-counters according to our three periods of interest.



The box shows the interquartile range, which contains the middle 50% of the data (from the 25th to the 75th percentile).


The horizontal line inside the box représents the median (the middle value of the dataset).


The whiskerw extend to the smallest and largest values within 1.5 times the interquartile range.



Our analyses by the test of Kruskal Wallis showed us that there did not seem to be a significant difference between our different periods in terms of the number of passages in front of eco-counters of the vulle de Montpellier. Indeed, we found a p-value of 0.16 and an H-value of 3.59. Thus, the differences do not seem to be significant.

title: Statistics
text:
Discussion

Our analyses seem to show that there is no significant difference in the number of cycles passing through eco-counters in the city of Montpellier between the periods before, during and after the Tour de France. However, if we look at the first graph we got, we can say that this evolution could be linked to other factors such as school and work holiday periods. Indeed, we note that there is a decrease at the beginning of the summer holiday period (July) and that seems to be accentuated during the August period. In addition, at the beginning of September, during the school year, there seems to be a strong increase in the number of bicycle trips.


Thus, it would be interesting to do more detailed analyses than those we have done, but also to look at the link with school holidays.

title: Statistics
text:
Conclusion

To conclude, from these preliminary analyses, we did not validate our hypothesis that the Tour de France had a positive impact on bicycle use in the city of Montpellier. But we have shown that it would be interesting to use other sources to justify these trends.

title: Website File Description:
text:
Website File Description:
The Website folder contains all the code that creates the website.
Basically, to launch the website on your machine, simply go to the index.qmd file and click on the first icon in the top right-hand corner, or use the ‘quarto render’ command in your terminal.

_quarto.yml
This file contains the basis for the creation of our site. Inside you can find the sections of our navigation bar and the pages they contain. This file is used overall to organise the different pages of the site and gives the links to these different pages.


index.qmd
This file corresponds to the home page of our site, where we present the context, analyses and data we have used.


styles.css
This file contains the personalisation parameters for the various parts of our site (titles, text, images, etc.). You can change the site’s appearance settings here.


footer.qmd
In this file, we can find what is in the footer, with the various associated pages.


analyses

map.qmd
This file contains the interactive maps we made using the Python codes in Code/Scripts, as well as the detailed analysis and interpretation of these maps.


statistics.qmd
This file contains the statistical analyses we carried out using the Python code in Code/Scripts, as well as the detailed analysis and interpretation of these results to answer our question.


video.qmd
This file contains the video we made using the Python codes in Code/Scripts, as well as a detailed analysis and interpretation of the video.



documentation

classes.qmd
This file contains the documentation for the classes we used in our Python code in Code/Scripts.


functions.qmd
This file contains the documentation for the functions we used in our Python code in Code/Scripts.


packages.qmd
This file contains the documentation for the packages we used in our Python code in Code/Scripts.



sources

sources.qmd
This file contains all the sources on which we have based this project. You can find articles, links and documentation that we have used ourselves.



footer

about_us.qmd
This file introduces the members of our team and gives a brief overview of our project.


MIT_licenses.qmd
This file contains the licence we have used to publish this project in total security.


privacy_policy.qmd
This file contains our privacy policy as well as the terms and conditions for the use of personal data that we have for this site.



docs
This file is the output file for our website. In other words, when you run a script with Quarto, it will automatically transform the Quarto code into html code. The files converted into html are stored in the docs folder.

title: Privacy policy
text:
EFFECTIVE DATE: 2024-01-22
Welcome to the site made by BikeProjectTeam7. We value your privacy and are committed to protecting your personal data. This Privacy Policy explains how we collect, use, and share your information.

title: Privacy policy
text:
Information We Collect

We may collect the following types of information: Personal Information: name, email address. Usage Data: information on how you use our site (e.g., pages visited, time spent on the site).


Cookies and Tracking Technologies: we do not use cookies.

title: Privacy policy
text:
How We Use Your Information

We use your information to:



Provide and maintain our services.


Improve the user experience on our site.

title: Privacy policy
text:
Data Sharing and Disclosure

We do not sell your personal data.

title: Privacy policy
text:
Your Rights

You have the right to:



Access your personal data.


Request correction or deletion of your data.


Opt out of data collection.

title: Privacy policy
text:
Contact Us

If you have any questions or concerns about this Privacy Policy, please contact us at your email address.

title: Functions
text:
convert_json_to_csv

Convert a JSON file containing EcoCompt data to a CSV file and filter the data for a specific date range. This function was used in the Code/Scripts/data_treatment_EcoCompt.py and Code/Scripts/ecoCompt_Download_and_Combine.py files to clean the data.


Parameters


input_file (str): the path to the JSON file to be converted.


output_dir (str): the directory where the resulting CSV file will be saved.




Returns


bool: True if the conversion is successful and results in valid data, False otherwise.




Notes


Filters data to include only dates between April 1, 2023, and October 31, 2023.


Removes rows with missing or invalid data, including null coordinates or essential fields.


The output CSV file is saved with the UTF-8-SIG encoding and uses a semicolon (;) as a delimiter.




Examples

Example: Convert a JSON file to CSV.

convert_json_to_csv(
    input_file="Data/Data_EcoCompt/example.json",
    output_dir="Data/Data_EcoCompt_clean"
)

title: Functions
text:
create_layer_for_date

Create a map layer for a given date, including paths and station markers. This function was used in the Code/Scripts/Prediction/code_bike_traffic_prediction.py file to make the predictions.


Parameters


date (str): date in the format 'YYYY-MM-DD'.


map_obj (folium.Map): The map object to add the layer to.


data (pandas.DataFrame): dataFrame containing path and station information for the date.




Returns


None: this function does not return a value but modifies the map object in place.




Examples

Example: create a map layer for July 10, 2023.

create_layer_for_date(
    date="2023-07-10", 
    map_obj=folium_map, 
    data=traffic_data
)

title: Functions
text:
download_file

Download a file from a URL, store it locally, and verify its integrity using a SHA256 hash. This function was used in the Code/Scripts/Prediction/code_bike_traffic_prediction.py file to make the predictions.


Parameters


url (str): the URL of the file to download.


output_path (str): path where the downloaded file will be saved.


expected_hash (str): the expected SHA256 hash of the file to verify its integrity.




Returns


None: this function does not return any value but raises an exception if the hash verification fails.




Examples

Example: download a file and verify its integrity.

download_file(
    url="https://example.com/data.csv",
    output_path="local_data/data.csv",
    expected_hash="abcdef1234567890abcdef1234567890abcdef1234567890abcdef1234567890"
)

title: Functions
text:
find_station_name

Find the name of the nearest station for a given geographic point by calculating distances using Geopy. This function was used in the Code/Scripts/Prediction/code_bike_traffic_prediction.py file to make the predictions.


Parameters


latitude (float): latitude of the target point.


longitude (float): longitude of the target point.


stations_df (pandas.DataFrame): dataFrame containing station data with columns 'latitude', 'longitude', and 'station_name'.




Returns


str: name of the nearest station.




Examples

Example: find the nearest station to a point.

find_station_name(
    latitude=43.6, longitude=3.9, 
    stations_df=stations
)

title: Functions
text:
is_within_radius

Check if a given point (latitude, longitude) is within a specified radius from a center point. This function was used in the Code/Scripts/Prediction/code_bike_traffic_prediction.py file to make the predictions.


Parameters


lat (float): latitude of the point to check.


lon (float): Longitude of the point to check.


center_lat (float): latitude of the center point.


center_lon (float): Longitude of the center point.


radius_km (float): the radius in kilometers.




Returns


bool: True if the point is within the radius, otherwise False.




Examples

Example: check if a point is within 15 km of Montpellier.

is_within_radius(
    lat=43.6, lon=3.9, 
    center_lat=43.6119, center_lon=3.8772, 
    radius_km=15
)

title: Functions
text:
Method: create_animation

Generate a video animation of the bike trips.


This method processes all frames in parallel, saving intermediate images to the disk, and combines them into a video file. This function was used in the Code/Scripts/Animation_Bike.py file to make the video.


Returns


None: this method does not return any value.




Notes


This method uses multiprocessing to parallelize frame generation, which can be resource-intensive.


Ensure that you have sufficient disk space for temporary files generated during the process.




Examples

Example: Generate the animation for the loaded dataset.

animation = BikeAnimation(input_file="data/trips.csv")
animation.create_animation()

title: Functions
text:
Method: precompute_route

Precompute the shortest route for a single trip. This function was used in the Code/Scripts/Animation_Bike.py file to generate the video.


Given a row containing the coordinates of departure and return points, this method calculates the shortest path using the OpenStreetMap graph.


Parameters


row (pandas.Series): a row from the input DataFrame containing trip information. The row must include the following columns:



'Departure_latitude', 'Departure_longitude'


'Return_latitude', 'Return_longitude'





Returns


list of int or None: a list of node IDs representing the shortest path in the graph, or None if the route cannot be computed.




Examples

Example: Precompute the shortest route for a single trip.

import pandas as pd

row = pd.Series({
    "Departure_latitude": 43.608,
    "Departure_longitude": 3.879,
    "Return_latitude": 43.610,
    "Return_longitude": 3.881
})

animation.precompute_route(row)
# Output: [123456, 123457, 123458, ...]

title: Functions
text:
process_all_json_files

Process all JSON files in a directory, converting each to a filtered CSV file in a target folder. This function was used in the Code/Scripts/data_treatment_EcoCompt.py and Code/Scripts/ecoCompt_Download_and_Combine.py files to clean the data.


Parameters

This function does not take parameters directly. Instead, it relies on a predefined folder structure for input and output.



Notes


Searches for JSON files in the Data/Data_EcoCompt directory relative to the script’s location.


Creates a directory Data/Data_EcoCompt_clean for saving the resulting CSV files if it does not already exist.


Displays a summary of successfully processed files and errors at the end.




Returns


None: the function does not return a value but logs progress and results to the console.




Examples

Example: Process all JSON files in the input directory.

# Running the function as part of the script
if __name__ == "__main__":
    process_all_json_files()

title: Functions
text:
safe_nearest_node

Securely find the nearest node in a graph for a given geographic point, handling exceptions. This function was used in the Code/Scripts/Prediction/code_bike_traffic_prediction.py file to make the predictions.


Parameters


graph (networkx.Graph): the road network graph.


latitude (float): Latitude of the target point.


longitude (float): longitude of the target point.




Returns


int: ID of the nearest node.




Examples

Example: find the nearest node in a road network.

safe_nearest_node(
    graph=osm_graph, 
    latitude=43.6, longitude=3.9
)

title: Packages
text: For the necessary codes for our project, we have used some packages to make our analysis.

title: Packages
text:
‘Numpy’

This package was used to perform efficient numerical computations, by manipulating multidimensional arrays and carrying out mathematical, statistical, and algebraic operations on these arrays.


For more details we can consult the documentation of this packages.

title: Packages
text:
‘Pandas’

This package was used to manipulate and analyze data, primarily by structuring data into DataFrames and performing operations like cleaning, filtering, aggregation, and statistical analysis.


For more details we can consult the documentation of this packages.

title: Packages
text:
‘Matplotlib’

This package was used to create graphical visualizations, such as line plots, histograms, bar charts, etc., to better understand and analyze the data.


For more details we can consult the documentation of this packages.

title: Packages
text:
‘Pooch’

This package was used to download and manage files reliably, especially for projects that require downloading external files (such as datasets) while ensuring version control and file integrity.


For more details we can consult the documentation of this packages.

title: Packages
text:
‘Geopy’

This package was used to calculate the distance between two geographical coordinates to determine the optimal route between multiple points in a logistics application.


For more details we can consult the documentation of this packages.

title: Packages
text:
‘Osmnx’

This package was used to download and analyze the bike-friendly road network of Montpellier from OpenStreetMap data. It enabled the visualization of the network, calculation of optimal routes for cycling, and analysis of the connectivity and structure of the cycling paths.


For more details we can consult the documentation of this packages.

title: Packages
text:
‘Seaborn’

This package was used to create elegant and informative statistical visualizations, such as distribution plots and scatterplots, to explore and understand the relationships between variables in the analyzed data


For more details we can consult the documentation of this packages.

title: Packages
text:
‘Tqdm’

This package was used to add progress bars to loops, allowing users to visually track the progress of a process, especially during long or repetitive tasks.


For more details we can consult the documentation of this packages.

title: Packages
text:
‘Moviepy’

This package was used to create a video from images, by assembling them in a specific order to form a smooth video sequence.


For more details we can consult the documentation of this packages.

title: Classes
text:
Class: BikeAnimation

Generate an animation of bike trips using geospatial data and OpenStreetMap.


This class processes bike trip data, computes routes on a graph derived from OpenStreetMap, and generates a video animation visualizing the trips over time.


Parameters


input_file (str): path to the CSV file containing trip data. The file must include the following columns:
'Departure_Date', 'Departure_Time', 'Return_Date', 'Return_Time',
'Departure_latitude', 'Departure_longitude', 'Return_latitude', 'Return_longitude'.


place_name (str, optional): name of the place to fetch the OpenStreetMap graph for, e.g., "Montpellier, France". Default is "Montpellier, France".


target_date (str or datetime-like, optional): filter trips for a specific date. If not specified, all dates in the input file are used. Default is None.


output_video (str, optional): path to the output video file. Default is "bike_animation.mp4".


fps (int, optional): frames per second for the output video. Default is 30.


minutes_per_second (int, optional): the speed ratio of real-world minutes to animation seconds. Default is 120 minutes per animation second.


sample_size (int, optional): number of trips to process from the input file. If None, all trips are processed. Default is None.




Attributes


df (pandas.DataFrame): the processed DataFrame containing trip data with additional computed fields.


G (networkx.MultiDiGraph): the graph representation of the OpenStreetMap data for the specified place.


nodes (geopandas.GeoDataFrame): GeoDataFrame containing the nodes of the graph.


total_frames (int): total number of frames to generate for the animation.


background_file (str): path to the saved background graph image.




Methods


precompute_route(row): calculates the shortest route between two points.


save_graph_background(): generates and saves a background image of the graph.


create_animation(): creates a video animation from the trips.




Note: for more details about the functions, visit the Functions section.



Examples

Create an animation for a dataset with the default settings.

animation = BikeAnimation(input_file="data/trips.csv", place_name="Paris, France")
animation.create_animation()

title: About us
text:
Global presentation

We are a team of 4 students at the Montpellier Faculty of Science. We are currently in the first year of our Masters in Statistics and Data Science. We are carrying out this project as part of the ‘Software Development’ teaching unit.

title: Interactive map
text:
Map context

On this page, we can see two interactive maps of bicycle traffic in the city of Montpellier: one corresponds to the predictions that we made from the data from January 2023 to June 2023, and the other on the actual data we have for this period. We decided to represent the two maps so that we could compare them and see if our prediction model is correct.


The interactive maps below show the forecast of cycling/ real cycling in the city of Montpellier from 10 July to 16 July 2023. These dates represent the intermediate week (2nd of 3 weeks) of the Tour de France.

title: Interactive map
text:
Maps

Predictions’ methods

The bicycle traffic predictions were made using the ‘Prophet’ model, a flexible tool for time series analysis. This model is well suited to data with temporal variations, making it an ideal choice for modelling cycle traffic. The prediction was influenced by factors such as days of the week, weather and local events (such as the Tour de France).


The predictions generated by Prophet have been integrated into the interactive map, making it possible to visualise predicted traffic levels on the various routes between stations.


To make this prediction, we decided to calculate only the shortest paths between each of the stations and not all the possible paths, for the sake of optimising journey times and also to make the map easier to read.



Graphs

In this maps, several days can be selected at the same time, but we advise you to select the days one after the other for consistent predictions.


Map of the cycling traffic forecast in Montpellier during the second week of the Tour de France:




Map of the cycling traffic in Montpellier during the second week of the Tour de France:





Cycle stations (Eco-counters)

The stations are represented by blue markers distributed around the city.



Paths between stations

The lines connecting the stations correspond to the paths between them. The colours of the lines vary according to the number of cycles predicted to pass along the route:



Dark red: Very high intensity (> 1500).


Light red: High intensity (1201-1500).


Orange: Moderate intensity (901-1200).


Yellow: Moderate intensity (601-900).


Light green: Low intensity (301-600).


Dark green: Very low intensity (≤ 300).




Geographical coverage

Predictions cover a 15km radius around Montpellier, including areas such as Saint-Jean-de-Védas, Castelnau-le-Lez, and Villeneuve-lès-Maguelone. We decided not to extend this area because bike journeys were becoming rare and we weren’t sure whether a station further away would actually correspond to a journey between that station and Montpellier or just a journey within its city.

title: Interactive map
text:
Comparisons

Between days

For comparisons between days of the week, we can use the two graphs as a basis. Both seem to show that there are far fewer cyclists during the 15-16 July period. This corresponds to the weekend and could therefore justify a drop in the number of cyclists compared with the week.



Between maps

If we want to check whether our predictions seem to match reality, we can compare our two maps. If we look in more detail, we can see that our predictions seem to reflect reality depending on the day (fewer people at weekends in both cases). However, our predictions seem to have underestimated the number of cyclists who pass in front of the Montpellier eco-counters because, if we look at the intensities of the passages, even vaguely we can see that there are many more colours in shades of red in the map representing the actual data than in our prediction map.

title: Videos
text:
Presentation

On this page, we will present you a video of the routes of the bicycles Velomag in the city of Montpellier for the date of Monday, July 10, 2023. This date corresponds to the first day of the second week of the Tour de France.


This allows us to deepen the results we have obtained in the maps game and will allow us to look at what is happening in terms of traffic of cyclists during the different hours of a day.


We decided to choose a day of the week because we could notice on the maps that there was less traffic during the weekend.

title: Videos
text:
Videos

Bike trafic of Monday 10 July 2023



Votre navigateur ne supporte pas les vidéos.

title: Videos
text:
Analyses

This video shows Velomagg bike journeys in Montpellier from midnight on Monday 10 July 2023 to 11.59pm on the same day.


The peak times are from 7.30am to 9am, around 1pm and from 5.30pm to around 9pm.


This seems to correspond to the start of work, the lunch break and the end of the working day.
